title: The Curfew Runner
description: Two men were stopped on the street past curfew by an enforcer patrol. One claims he was visiting his girlfriend. The other says he was walking home from a late shift. Review the permits and determine who violated curfew.
stateChoice: Convict the citizen who violated curfew without valid authorization.

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: You were stopped on Korda Street at 23:15, well past the 22:00 curfew. Why were you out?

responseSequence: I was visiting my girlfriend, Ana. She lives on Korda Street.
We're registered with the Council. I have a visitation permit.
I... my permit is for daytime visits. I know.
Ana's shift at the textile mill ends at 22:00. By the time she gets home and I get there, it's past curfew. The permit doesn't account for that.

clickableClues.clickableText: my permit is for daytime visits
clickableClues.noteText: <person>Lazar Radic</person> admits his visitation permit is daytime-only and that he knowingly violated curfew because <person>Ana</person>'s work schedule makes daytime visits impossible

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: This checkpoint photo shows you on Korda Street at 23:10. Five minutes before the enforcer stopped you.

responseSequence: Yes, that's me. I was walking to Ana's building.
I wasn't hiding. I wasn't sneaking. I was just going to see my girlfriend.

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: Your relationship with Ana is registered. Why not apply for an evening permit?

responseSequence: I tried. The clerk said evening permits are only for married couples.
We've been together eleven months. But the system says we're not serious enough for evening visits.

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: Your visitation permit clearly says 08:00 to 20:00. You were out at 23:15. That's a curfew violation.

responseSequence: I know what the permit says.
Ana works until ten at night. When am I supposed to see her? The system doesn't care that shift workers exist.

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: You knowingly broke curfew. You understand that's a violation?

responseSequence: I understand the rule. I just think the rule doesn't understand people.
Charge me if you have to. I'd do it again.

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: The other man stopped with you — Ivan Cerovic — do you know him?

responseSequence: Never seen him before. We were just on the same street when the enforcer stopped us both.

lawyeredUpResponses: I went to see my girlfriend. That's my crime. Charge me.
What more do you want me to say?
rattledResponses: What happens to Ana if I get sent away?
We're registered. We did everything right. Except the hours.
Please... it was just a visit.
shutdownResponses: Do what you have to do.

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: You were also stopped past curfew. Why were you on the street at 23:15?

responseSequence: I was walking home from work. The boiler at Factory 12 had a pressure fault.
I stayed late to fix it. My foreman can confirm.

clickableClues.noteText: <person>Ivan Cerovic</person> claims he was working overtime at <location>Factory 12</location> to fix a boiler pressure fault and was walking home when stopped

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: You say you were working late. Do you have documentation?

responseSequence: I have an overtime permit. It's... well, it expired last month.
But the work log at Factory 12 will show I was there until 22:40. The foreman signed me out.

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: Your overtime permit expired last month. You know that means you were technically unauthorized to be out?

responseSequence: I applied for renewal three weeks ago. Still waiting.
The boiler doesn't care about paperwork. If I don't fix it, the factory doesn't run in the morning.

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: This checkpoint photo shows two figures on Korda Street at 23:10. Can you confirm that's you?

responseSequence: That looks like me, yes. I was walking from the factory toward Block D.
The young man — I don't know him. We were just on the same street.

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: The factory timesheet confirms you clocked out at 22:40. That checks out.

responseSequence: Of course it does. I've worked at that factory for nineteen years.
I fix the boiler. I go home. That's my life.

lawyeredUpResponses: Check the factory log. I was working.
My permit expired. I know. I applied for renewal.
I'm a boiler technician. I fix things. That's all.
rattledResponses: I've worked there nineteen years. Never had a problem.
If my permit had come through on time, we wouldn't be here.
Am I really being charged for doing my job?

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: You stopped both men at 23:15 on Korda Street. Describe what you saw.

responseSequence: Standard patrol. Spotted two males walking in opposite directions on Korda Street.
Both past curfew. Detained both for processing.

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: The checkpoint camera captured both men at 23:10. Did they appear to be together?

responseSequence: No. They were walking in opposite directions.
The young one was heading east toward the apartment blocks. The older one was heading west toward Block D.

tagInteractions.tagQuestion: The older man says he was coming from Factory 12. Did he look like he'd been working?

responseSequence: He was wearing work coveralls. Smelled like grease and steam.
His story seemed legitimate. But expired permit is expired permit.

lawyeredUpResponses: I detained them as per protocol.
rattledResponses: I'm just doing my job, analyst.
Is there a problem with my report?
I stopped them. I filed the report. That's it.

steps.description: Review the enforcer report and checkpoint photo to understand the situation
Examine permits to determine who had valid authorization to be out
Cross-check Ivan's work alibi against the factory timesheet
